You fail to understand that without the riots and fires, the system probably never would not have responded. It was precisely because people expressed their rage at the injustice of continued murders by an unaccountable police department, by turning Baltimore upside down, that they finally attracted national attention and forced the system to address their grievances instead of ignoring them. If the people had done nothing to threaten the power structure, the system had no reason to finally respond as it did today.

He has been consistently on message for decades. i video taped him in speaking in Plainfield, NJ in 1984 for a community access broadcast, and while little has changed in his message, the situation has gotten much worse.

Agreed and interesting enough the TV show called "Silicon Valley" had a plot based on this analysis last week. The company asked the VC to CUT their investment so the founders could keep hold of their jobs etc. Slower, more modest roll-out better business in the long run. (A point made by a woman to the man who invented the company - -some new Cloud app -- who in turn made it to the woman who ran the VC company, because of the sudden death of the head of the VC). Weirdly anticipating Dave Goldberg's sudden death...Would have been smart of the Upshot to consider how Hollywood/CAble TV are alos selling these VC stars in their product as well --The Social Network, the Steve Jobs bio-pics, and "SV" itself.

Exactly. Unfortunately these days the so-called entrepreneurs don't really have the skin in the game. It's all someone else's money, and if the idea/venture fails, who cares? It's almost a badge of honor to fail fast and move just as quickly to the next silly idea. All it matters is, if you can attract the silly money to come in the first time, those silly money (and investors like Andreessen) will follow them too.

These days, rarely anyone has the perseverance to do the grunge work, and investors don't have to patience to stay on for more than two years. If they don't get bought out (by the next silly guy like Yahoo or Microsoft or Facebook or Google) or IPO'ed, they'd move on. In today's environment, it would not have allowed the likes of Steve Jobs to tough it out and make sure their product is just right, the operations (including manufacturing) is perfect, before they go out to the market. And look what happens to Google Glass or even Google Wave (which once upon a time was meant to be revolutionary, yet died before as stillborn), though Google (much like a well-funded startup) can afford to lose it, and start over.
One wonders what market-wrenching system crashes are going to happen as these quickly cobbled enterprises scale and expand out to other related businesses but their architecture cannot handle it.

As a start-up CEO I look at many of AH investments and see reasonably good ideas overwhelmed with way too much cash at ego-inflating valuations. These mostly young entrepreneurs mistake cash balances with real business success and start spending on overpriced offices, unsustainable perks, expensive marketing campaigns and bewitch themselves with metrics like daily active users, session times and virality. Nothing is less beneficial to a start-up than to have too much money and a patron that encourages burn rates that no real business could ever have in the name of disruption. Add this to the new trend of allowing founders to take out cash in B-round financings creating millionaires long before their businesses are sound and you have a real Hollywood delusion. Once you are treated as a star, you'll never share a dressing room ever again.

What that line means is she will cut social Security, Medicare, Medicaid, and the ACA subsidies for the working class. Republicans may hate her candidacy but they will love working with her to cut these programs and/or privatize them.

With Hillary as the Dem nominee, the Reps don't need to win the presidency; she'll do their dirty work for them and the Dem Party will continue its rightward drift.

The list of things Bernie Sanders has done right, just because that's how he is, is to join SNCC during the Civil Rights movement. He gets better from there.

We need someone who is principled, trustworthy, beholden only to those compatriots who aren't registered as an LLC or corp, empathetic, knowledgeable on all fronts, and who has the courage to see through the myriad of reforms our nation now needs. Bernie is that man. The others? Not so much.

Barack Obama turned out to be the man for the times when Hillary was thought to be the shoo-in. It isn't out of the realm of the possible that, in its wisdom, America will think better of her again.
She heard peaceful protestors. And recognized, perhaps, that broken windows are fixable, but broken spines are not.

Sanders accomplishments as mayor are quite impressive.

"My administration took on the special interests. Against the wishes of developers and railroad, we created a people-oriented waterfront and bike path on Lake Champlain. We developed the first municipal housing land trust for affordable housing. We won recognition for urban beautification by planting thousands of trees and we made improvements to our streets and sidewalks. We implemented the largest environmental program in the state’s history by building a waste-water facility to prevent untreated waste from going into the lake. We started a Youth Office which created a day care center, a little-league program, after-school programs and a teen center – all of which exist today. We were the first city in Vermont to break its dependence on the regressive property tax. We made changes in the police department, moving in the direction of community policing. We started a successful Arts Council and Women’s Council. Burlington is now regarded as one of the most livable small cities in America."

Sanders on obstructionism:

"I took office with 11 out of 13 members of the City Council in strong opposition to my agenda. If you think Republicans have been obstructionist to President Obama, that was nothing compared to what my supporters and I experienced. One year later, in support of what I and my coalition had accomplished and wanted to do, candidates that I supported defeated a number of the obstructionists."

Bernie Sanders didn't simply govern Burlington, VT well. He transformed it. He knows how to run things. He'll run a great campaign.

The only thing he won't run is a negative ad against an opponent. Never. His campaigns are always about issues and policies for the Common Good and he is eloquent in getting that message out.

His decision to run for president is probably the best thing that's happened for progressives, the middle class and the poor in decades. Bernie Sanders was a founding father of the Progressive Caucus in Congress.

Let the race begin!

If you lived in a community that was under siege, you would probably realize that many of those residents view the police as their enemy and are prone to running from them to avoid whatever confrontation the police are cooking up. Happens all the time. When you see someone with a gun and virtually unlimited power that you know is out to get you, maybe you run.

And whatever the case, we now know that he didn't run because he had committed a crime. There was no crime. He was unlawfully arrested, probably because the police officers feelings were hurt that he chose not to stick around to be interrogated and demeaned.
It;s certainly time for a candidate who speaks their own mind, rather than what tested well in focus groups (or among the lunatic fringe).

I only used two fillets but made the same amount of butter concoction -- in truth, if I used more fillets, I'd likely double the butter, garlic, anchovy and capers.  Overall, a wonderful delight! I need to make this again quite soon.

I'm not a criminal law guy and this is not meant to advise Marilyn J. Mosby, who, I a sure is far more knowledgeable and competent in prosecuting.

But, just a thought, Zimmerman was indicted for murder. I believe if he had been indicted for manslaughter in the first degree, Zimmerman would be behind bars.

That's all easy for you to say from the side of not suffering in a community under siege by a military style police force that feels emboldened to stop who they like, when they like, regardless of whether they have reason or not. If you lived in a city (such as NYC) where just walking down the block was reason enough to get pushed around by cops, maybe you'd be whistling a different tune.

I find it interesting that the article makes clear that the family was in agreement that he would never want to be hooked up to machines, and he was taken off the ventilator, and survived. He was sent to hospice, but, what condition was he in ? What quality of life would be have ? Is he on oxygen continuously ? Is he in pain ? What is his level of cognition ? How long would he have to endure this ? If there were no intervention at all, which might be what his wishes were (but it's not that clear) he might have been spared all of this. It's just crazy. And rarely ever clean cut.

I think it's good that discussions like this are popping up more often, and people are becoming more educated. I wonder though, if we as a society wrangle endlessly over a woman's right to make decisions about her own body, are we really mature enough to handle the ethical and moral nuances needed for an intelligent discussion about end of life decisions ? I'm not so sure we are yet.

Not if you live in a community in which you don't trust the police. As we know from this situation, they unlawfully arrested a man simply because he didn't stick around for the interrogation. Hurting police officers feelings by not wanting to be searched and interrogated for no reason, isn't sufficient justification to do what they did to Freddie Gray.

Jim, that is true.  But many of the commenters over the past two weeks wanted to equate this only to racial profiling by white officers.  There is an underbelly to police brutality that simple answers about black people and white cops do not encompass.  There are brutal officers of any racial, ethic or cultural background.  Baltimore has a police force that is almost half African American.  They, too, can have an "us vs them" mentality.  One of the two superior officers, who theoretically should be more judicious, was black.  In fact, 's. Mosby said that this sergeant checked Mr. Gray's condition and he was not responsive, but she did not request EMTs. The blue line operates among cops of many colors.

The unjustified arrest was perpetrated by three white officers; declaring a switchblade was obviously an excuse for their behavior; what I am not reading, surprisingly, is the arrest is the direct result of racial profiling for the odds a white citizen arrested without cause and treated in such way are low, not only in Ferguson but pretty much nationwide.

The media should take time to note that 3 of the 6 accused officers are African-American. Perhaps what we're seeing the last few months is not specifically a problem of police officers mistreating African-Americans but instead a problem of police officers mistreating people of all races.
Where is the evidence that race played any role in this? Keep in mind, 3 of the six officers accused are African-American.

What happens when the defendants move to change venue, they do, and the jury in that location doesn't give the jury Ms Mosby seems to suggest is already in the bag.  She didn't even have time to review the reports or ask questions.  I think the yard signs for Ms Mosby as the Baltimore DA will be going up pretty soon- good politics, bad lawyering
